name: The Noblest Half
description: Armed with a time and space traveling suit, Spock has been interfering with Starfleet missions in the past, present, and future, often for the worse. Can you help Spock's loved ones determine why he's acting so illogically?
rules:
-- There are two Phases to this Event! Each Phase is individually timed.
-- In this Hybrid Event, you will complete Faction Missions in one phase, and Supply Missions in another phase.
-- Unique Faction Missions and Supply Missions are available during the event. Open the Event to access them.
-- Using any version of Grayson, Sarek, M. Burnham, Vulcans or EV Suit Spock will provide a bonus to Faction Missions and Supply Missions.
-- Every Faction or Supply Mission you complete earns you Event Victory Points. Collect Event Victory Points to unlock Threshold Rewards!
-- Community Rewards are also available during Phase 2 only. Collect Event Victory Points to unlock these rewards before the phase change!
-- In this event, Squadrons may also compete to advance up the Squadron leaderboards. Join a Squadron to get more rewards!
bonus_text: Crew Bonus: Grayson, Sarek, M. Burnham, Vulcans or EV Suit Spock
rewards_teaser: Reach Rank 1 by gaining Victory Points from Event Missions!

featured_crew.name: Solok
featured_crew.flavor: When reuniting with an old colleague, Captain Solok seeks to repair his ship and provoke an emotional response through competition.

featured_crew.name: Sarek
featured_crew.flavor: Hiding his heart affliction, Sarek stands tall against a particularly tenacious Tellarite.

next_threshold_rewards.name: Chronitons
next_threshold_rewards.flavor: Chronitons allow your crew to take action in these chaotic times. Use Chronitons to replay parts of past missions via the Timeline.

screens.text: "Spock is acting illogically. He has obtained a spacesuit capable of acting as both temporal and interstellar method of transportation, and been observed interfering in several Starfleet operations, in the past, present, and future."
"Spock is acting troubled. There is a difference, Michael. Emotional reasons are just as valid as others. But I don't know what would have made him want to interfere with Starfleet's mission."

"Once you eliminate the logical, whatever remains, however illogical, must be the truth--isn't that the saying? Let us delve first into Vulcan and human history. If there is nothing logical there, then we can examine Spock's... mental state."
